info.game_comments: (Sofia: We've got some boxing clues that'll knock you out, coming up on Jeopardy!)

double_jeopardy_round: THAT'S THE STORY OF MY LIFE

(1, 1).clue: 80% of this molasses-based potent potable consumed in the U.S. is imported from Puerto Rico

(3, 1).clue: Britney, Christina & Justin were part of the Mickey Mouse one

(4, 1).clue: In 622 Muhammad fled this city; in 630 he came back with 10,000 followers & captured it

(5, 1).clue: In the 1940s Borden's came up with this companion for Elsie to be the symbol for its new white glue

(6, 1).clue: It can be a king, a queen or a butterfly

(1, 2).clue: In 1917 the Second Organic Act, also called the Jones Act, gave this to Puerto Ricans

(2, 2).clue: 2001:"Good evening, Clarice!  Just like old times"

(3, 2).clue: Chambers Dictionary says its "sense as a baseball infield area appeared...in 1875"

(4, 2).clue: The opening of this in 1869 cut 4,000 miles & weeks of sailing off trips

(5, 2).clue: His first appearance on the cover of Mad was in 1956 as a write-in candidate for president

(6, 2).clue: Dishes cooked a la Florentine contain this vegetable

(1, 3).clue: Now a popular tourist attraction, El Morro Fortress was built by the Spaniards to guard this city's bay

(3, 3).clue: Kasper Gutman tells him, "By gad, sir, you're a character"

(4, 3).clue: Einhard's "Life of" this Frankish ruler says he almost doubled the size of the realm his father Pepin left him

(5, 3).clue: In 1957 the New York Evening Enquirer expanded its scope & renamed itself this

(6, 3).clue: Nationality that can precede auction, oven & treat

(1, 4).clue: In 1509 he became Puerto Rico's first governor; 4 years later he sailed for Florida

(2, 4).clue: 1967:"Mrs. Robinson, do you think we could say a few words to each other first this time?"

(3, 4).clue: It gets a 10 on the standard Mohs scale

(4, 4).clue: It was under this czar that Russia went on the Julian calendar used in the West; he liked Western stuff

(5, 4).clue: Unhappy with the quality of these, Dr. Amar Bose designed his own & formed a company to sell them

(6, 4).clue: It's what Canadians call Bigfoot, eh?

(1, 5).clue: In June musicians take part in a festival honoring this cellist who lived there the last 17 years of his life

(2, 5).clue: 1989:"Where does he get those wonderful toys?"

(3, 5).clue: It's a synonym for core or center

(4, 5).clue: He was the junker, or landowner, whom Prussia's Wilhelm I chose to be his prime minister in 1862

(5, 5).clue: Milan company known for its tires & sexy calendars

(6, 5).clue: Derived from Yiddish, it means to complain, with a little whining thrown in for good measure

(1, 1).clue: The Comstock Lode on Mt. Davidson in western Nevada was the richest find of this element in the U.S.

(2, 1).clue: In 1986 Johnny Cash recorded a religious song called this, the opposite of his nickname

(3, 1).clue: Friar with an everlasting name in the Bluegrass State

(4, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew at Gleason's Gym in New York City)  This great champ who trained at Gleason's Gym invented the "Rope-a-dope" technique to tire his opponents

(5, 1).clue: For losing 3 pairs of these, the 3 Little Kittens temporarily lost pie privileges in a Mother Goose rhyme

(1, 2).clue: Baking soda, salt & lye all contain this element

(2, 2).clue: (Hi, I'm Richie McDonald) They say this is good news, but not in my band Lonestar's No. 1 song with this title

(3, 2).clue: Trumpeter Armstrong, who could be found in a gulf state

(4, 2).clue: After a knockdown during a match, the standing boxer must retire to one of these

(5, 2).clue: This football team from New York state lost 4 straight Super Bowls

(1, 3).clue: Plants absorb its isotope 90 generated by nuclear fallout

(2, 3).clue: The song "On the Beach at" this place, which became a stateside standard, was first published in Honolulu in 1915

(3, 3).clue: The Woolf is at the door as this stately name

(4, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew)  From the Middle English for "thrust", it's a term used for practice fighting

(5, 3).clue: 1 of the 3 losing numbers on a first roll in craps

(6, 3).clue: An athlete:"It's Not About the Bike"

(1, 4).clue: Element No. 16, it's used in vulcanization

(2, 4).clue: Undistinguished congressman Joseph Hopkinson is remembered for writing "Hail" this, now the VP's intro music

(3, 4).clue: The Everglades & this first name of "Tank Girl" Petty are found in the Sunshine State

(4, 4).clue: By setting many of the rules still used today, the 8th Marquess of this turned boxing from fisticuffs into an art form

(5, 4).clue: In Genesis he loses one garment to his brothers & another to Potiphar's wife

(1, 5).clue: It was named for the moon as it was found with tellurium which was named for the Earth

(2, 5).clue: In this 1938 song the title line is followed by "Where you're terrific if you're even good"

(3, 5).clue: German actress & drama coach Hagen who's been hangin' around a Western state

(4, 5).clue: (Cheryl) The subject of the film "Raging Bull", this Gleason's Gym trainee held the middleweight title from 1949 to 1951

(5, 5).clue: It's an atom that can become electrically charged by losing one or more electrons

(0, 0).clue: Of the genus Phascolarctos, it's 23-33" tall with a stout gray or brown body, a big round nose & strong claws
